document.docAuthor: Kato, Saori, Hamasaki, Katsuyuki, Dan, Shigeki & Kitada, Shuichi
document.masterDocTitle: Larval development of the land hermit crab Coenobita violascens Heller, 1862 (Decapoda, Anomura, Coenobitidae) described from laboratory-reared material

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Larval development of the land hermit crab Coenobita violascens Heller, 1862 (Decapoda, Anomura, Coenobitidae) described from laboratory-reared material

subSubSection.paragraph: First zoea
Intermoult period . 4.0 ± 0.2 ( 3–5 ) days; N = 57 .

Carapace (
Fig. 1
A, F). Rostrum tapered, long, extending beyond the tips of antennules, faintly carinate; posterolateral margins of carapace rounded; eyes sessile.

Antennule (
Fig. 2
A). Uniramous, unsegmented, with 3 ( 2 ) terminal aesthetascs, 3 terminal setae and long subterminal seta.

Antenna (
Fig. 2
B). Biramous; protopod with serrated spine distally at base of exopod; endopod unsegmented, fused to protopod, with 2 long and 1 short terminal setae; exopod (scaphocerite) with 10 setae on mesial and distal margins, spine on outer distal margin and fine setules on inner margin.
Mandible (not illustrated). Asymmetrical dentate; palp bud absent.

Maxillul e (
Fig. 2
C). Coxal endite with 7 ( 5 ) setae; basal endite with 2 strong denticulate spines and 2 setae; endopod 3 -segmented, distal segment with 2 terminal setae.

Maxilla (
Fig. 2
D). Coxal endite bilobed, with 6–7 + 3–4 setae; basal endite bilobed, with 4–5 + 3–4 setae; endopod bilobed, with 2 + 1–2 setae and fine setules on outer margin; exopod (scaphognathite) margin with 4–5 plumose setae and fine setules on inner margin.

First maxilliped (
Fig. 2
E). Coxa naked; basis with hook-like process plus 2 fine setae at proximal end of inner face and with 6–8 ventral setae arranged 1 + 1 + 2–3 + 2–3 ; endopod 5 -segmented, with 3, 2, 1, 2, 4 + I setae (Roman numeral denoting dorsolateral seta), first 3 segments with some setules; exopod incompletely 2 -segmented, with 4 terminal natatory plumose setae.

Second maxilliped (
Fig. 2
F). Coxa without seta; basis with 3 ( 2 ) setae arranged 1 + 2 ( 1 ); endopod 4 -segmented, with 2, 2, 2 ( 1 ), 4 ( 3 )+ I setae, 2 nd and 3 rd segments with some setules; exopod as in first maxilliped.

Third maxilliped (
Fig. 2
G). Two-segmented uniramous bud.

Pleon (
Fig. 1
A, F). With 5 pleomeres; pleomere 2 with conspicuous, slightly curved mediodorsal spine; pleomeres 3 and 4 each with small mid-dorsal spinule; pleomere 5 with large mid-dorsal spine and pair of large posterolateral spines.

Telson (
Fig. 2
H). With 7 + 7 marginal processes, outermost ( 1 st) fixed spine, 2 nd fine seta, 3 rd– 7 th setae; posteromedian notch semicircular; very short marginal setae between processes and on median notch.
Second zoea
Intermoult period . 3.3 ± 0.5 ( 2–4 ) days; N = 57 .

Carapace (
Fig. 1
B, G). More noticeable rostral carina; eyes stalked; otherwise unchanged.

Antennule (
Fig. 3
A). Uniramous, with 3 ( 2 ) terminal aesthetascs, 4 terminal setae and 1 long and 1–2 short subterminal setae.

Antenna (
Fig. 3
B). Protopod with small spine near junction of scaphocerite; otherwise unchanged.
Mandible (not illustrated). Essentially unchanged.

Maxillule (
Fig. 3
C). Coxal endite with 6–7 setae; basal endite with 4 strong denticulate spines; otherwise unchanged.

Maxilla (
Fig. 3
D). Coxal endite with 6–7 + 3–4 setae; basal endite with 4–5 + 4 setae; endopod with 2 + 2 setae; scaphognathite with 5–8 marginal plumose setae.

First maxilliped (
Fig. 3
E). Basis with 7–8 setae arranged 1 + 1 + 3 + 2–3 ; endopod with 2–3 + I, 1–2 + I, 1 + I, 2, 4 + I setae; exopod with 6 terminal natatory plumose setae.

Second maxilliped (
Fig. 3
F). Basis with 3 setae arranged 1 + 2 ; endopod with 2, 2+ I, 2 + I, 4 + I setae; exopod as in 1 st maxilliped.

Third maxilliped (
Fig. 3
G). Endopod bud with small terminal seta; exopod 2 -segmented, with 5 terminal natatory plumose setae.
Pereiopods. Small buds visible.

Pleon (
Fig. 1
B, H). Unchanged.

Telson (
Fig. 3
H). With 8 + 8 processes including additional pair of setae; median notch indistinct.
Third zoea
Intermoult period . 3.4 ± 0.5 ( 3–4 ) days; N = 57 .

Carapace (
Fig. 1
C, H). Essentially unchanged.

Antennule (
Fig. 4
A). Protopod with 2 long setae at base of endopod and 2–3 setae on opposite side; endopod as a small bud with 1 long seta; exopod with 2–3 terminal aesthetascs and 3 terminal setae.

Antenna (
Fig. 4
B). Endopod articulated with protopod, bearing terminal seta; scaphocerite with 13–14 setae; otherwise unchanged.
Mandible (not illustrated). Essentially unchanged.

Maxillule (
Fig. 4
C).Coxal endite with 7–8 setae; otherwise unchanged.

Maxilla (
Fig. 4
D). Scaphognathite with 10–11 marginal plumose setae; otherwise unchanged.

First maxilliped (
Fig. 4
E). Endopod with 3 + I, 2 + I, 1 + I, 2, 4 + I setae; otherwise unchanged.

Second maxilliped (
Fig. 4
F).Unchanged.

Third maxilliped (
Fig. 5
G). Exopod with 6 terminal natatory plumose setae; otherwise unchanged.
Pereiopods. Four obvious buds.

Pleon (
Figs. 1
C, H, 4 H). With 6 pleomeres; armature of pleomeres 2–5 unchanged; pleomere 6 with a mediodorsal spine.

Uropods (
Fig. 4
H). Exopod, endopod and protopod fused; endopods naked, much smaller than exopod; exopod with 8 setae along posterior and inner margins and fine setules on mesial margin.

Telson (
Fig. 4
H). With 8 + 1 + 8 processes; a short median seta flanked by 8 processes; outermost ( 1 st) fixed spine, 2 nd fine seta, 3 rd seta, 4 th larger fixed spine, 5 th– 8 th setae.
Fourth zoea
Intermoult period . 5.7 ± 0.5 ( 5–7 ) days; N = 57 .

Carapace (
Fig. 1
D, I). Unchanged.

Antennule (
Fig. 5
A). Protopod with mesial seta, 4 long setae at base of endopod and 3–4 setae on opposite side; endopod bud developed; exopod with mesial seta, 3 terminal aesthetascs and 4 terminal setae.

Antenna (
Fig. 5
B). Endopod 2 -segmented, almost as long as exopod; scaphocerite with 14–16 setae; otherwise unchanged.

Mandible (
Fig. 5
C). Palp bud present.

Maxillule (
Fig. 5
D). Coxal endite with 8 setae; basal endite with 6 strong denticulate spines and 2 setae; endopod 3 -segmented, 2 nd segment with 0–1 seta and distal segment with 2 setae.

Maxilla (
Fig. 5
E). Coxal endite with 8–9 + 4 setae; basal endite with 4–5 4–5 setae; endopod with 2 + 2 setae; scaphognathite with 13–15 marginal plumose setae on distal lobe.

First maxilliped (
Fig. 5
F). Unchanged.

Second maxilliped (
Fig. 5
G). Exopod with 8 ( 7 ) terminal natatory plumose setae; otherwise unchanged.

Third maxilliped (
Fig. 5
H). Unchanged.
Pereiopods. Five buds present.

Pleon (
Fig. 1
D, I). Pleomeres 2–5 with pleopod buds (
Fig. 5
J); otherwise unchanged.

Uropods (
Fig.
5
I). Exopod, endopod and protopod articulated; endopod with 6–7 setae and inner marginal row of fine setules; exopod with sharp posterolateral marginal process, 11–12 setae along posterior and inner margins and fine setules on inner margin.

Telson (
Fig.
5
I). Unchanged.
Megalopa
Duration from hatching to the megalopal stage. 16.4 ± 0.8 ( 15–19 ) days; N = 57 .

Carapace (
Fig. 1
E). Shorter than pleon, including telson; rostrum rounded, extending beyond front; eyes and eyestalks well developed.

Antennule (
Fig. 6
A). Biramous; peduncle 3 -segmented, each segment with some setae; endopod unsegmented, with mesial seta and 2–4 terminal setae; exopod unsegmented, with a total of 8 aesthetascs and 1 mesial and 2–4 terminal setae.

Antenna (
Fig. 6
B). Peduncle 5 -segmented; supernumerary segment present; acicle rounded knob with dorsal seta; flagellum with 7 articles, setal formula 0, 0–2, 2– 4 , 0–1, 3–4, 2 ( 3 ), 5–8 .

Mandible (
Fig. 6
C). Reduced and simplified; palp 3 -segmented, 1 st segment with 0–1 setae and distal ( 3 rd) segment with 7–9 setae.

Maxillule (
Fig. 6
D). Coxal endite with 14–16 setae; basal endite with 10–14 setae and 12–16 spinules; endopod unsegmented, with well-developed, recurved external lobe, internal lobe with 2 setae on inner margin.

Maxilla (
Fig. 6
E). Coxal endite with 25–29 (not all illustrated) + 5–6 setae; basal endite with 6–9 + 10–12 setae; endopod unsegmented, with 0–2 setae; scaphognathite with 51–56 marginal plumose setae.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Coenobita violascens
, whole animals. Dorsal view: (A) first zoea; (B) second zoea; (C) third zoea; (D) fourth zoea; (E) megalopa. Lateral view: (F) first zoea; (G) second zoea; (H) third zoea; (I) fourth zoea. Scale bars = 1.0 mm.

FIGURE 2.
Coenobita violascens
, first zoea: (A) antennule; (B) antenna; (C) maxillule; (D) maxilla; (E) first maxilliped; (F) second maxilliped; (G) third maxilliped; (H) telson. Scale bars = 0.1 mm.

FIGURE 3.
Coenobita violascens
, second zoea: (A) antennule; (B) antenna; (C) maxillule; (D) maxilla; (E) first maxilliped; (F) second maxilliped; (G) third maxilliped; (H) telson. Scale bars = 0.1 mm.

FIGURE 4.
Coenobita violascens
, third zoea: (A) antennule; (B) antenna; (C) maxillule; (D) maxilla; (E) first maxilliped; (F) second maxilliped; (G) third maxilliped; (H) telson and uropods. Scale bars = 0.1 mm.

FIGURE 5.
Coenobita violascens
, fourth zoea: (A) antennule; (B) antenna; (C) mandibles; (D) maxillule; (E) maxilla; (F) first maxilliped; (G) second maxilliped; (H) third maxilliped; (I) telson and uropods; (J) pleopod. Scale bars = 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
First maxilliped (
Fig. 6
F). Coxal lobe with 5–8 setae; basal lobe with 14–17 setae; endopod unsegmented, often with terminal seta; exopod with strong lateral constriction, 5–8 marginal plumose setae. Second maxilliped (
Fig. 6
G). Coxa and basis with several setae, respectively; endopod 4 -segmented, each segment with several setae; exopod two-segmented, with 2–4 setae along inner margin of basal segment, distal segment with 7 terminal plumose setae.

Third maxilliped (
Fig. 6
H). Coxa and basis with several setae, respectively; endopod 5 -segmented, ultimate and penultimate segments heavily setose, remaining segments with scattered setae; exopod 3 -segmented, penultimate segment with mesial seta.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6.
Coenobita violascens
, megalopa: (A) antennule; (B) antenna; (C) mandible; (D) maxillule; (E) maxilla; (F) first maxilliped; (G) second maxilliped; (H) third maxilliped; (I) telson and uropods; (J) pleopod. Scale bars = 0.1 mm.

FIGURE 7.
Coenobita violascens
, megalopa: (A–E) pereiopods 1–5, respectively. Scale bars = 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Pereiopods (
Fig. 7
A–E). Chelipeds similar; dactyl subequal to palm in length, each segment with scattered setae; ambulatory legs with dactyl terminating in corneous claw surrounded by setae, each segment with scattered setae; 4 th pereiopod with scattered short setae on each segment; propodus with short and long setae plus marginal and submarginal corneous scales; dactyl terminating in corneous claw, with scattered short setae and single long seta; 5 th pereiopod with scattered short setae on each segment; propodus and dactyl with several long, curved setae and corneous scales plus scattered short setae.

Pleon (
Fig. 1
E). Six unarmed somites with scattered, laterally paired dorsal setae; biramous pleopods on pleomeres 2–5 (
Fig. 6
J); exopod well developed, with 9 plumose setae; endopod simple lobe with 2 small coiled subterminal setae.

Tail fan (
Fig.
6
I). Telson slightly wider than long, with scattered, laterally paired setae on dorsal surface; posterior margin with 9 long plumose setae and 2–3 short setae laterally; uropods biramous, symmetrical; exopod with 21 long plumose setae and 8–10 corneous scales marginally, plus 3–4 submarginal short setae; endopod margin with 13 long plumose setae, 4–7 short marginal setae and 3–6 corneous scales; protopod with 3 setae anterior to exopod base and 1 short seta between endopod and telson.
